docs.snippet: With some notable caveats, many American companies yesterday endorsed the World Trade Organization's new rules for negotiating a trade agreement, arguing that the potential for increased exports outweighs the damage a few industries might suffer.   ...
docs.lead_paragraph: With some notable caveats, many American companies yesterday endorsed the World Trade Organization's new rules for negotiating a trade agreement, arguing that the potential for increased exports outweighs the damage a few industries might suffer. ''We view the new round of negotiations authorized at the W.T.O. meeting as a hunting license for bringing down tariffs,'' said Franklin J. Vargo, an international trade expert with the National Association of Manufacturers.
docs.abstract: Many American companies endorse World Trade Organization's new rules for negotiating trade agreement, arguing that potential for increased exports outweighs damage few industries might suffer; agreement reached by more than 140 trade ministers gathered in Doha, Oatar, sets rules for new round of tariff-lowering trade negotiations (M)

headline.main: U.S. Companies Largely Back Trade Decisions

docs.snippet: The four-time champion Brazil and the three-time winner Germany qualified for the World Cup soccer finals next year in Japan and South Korea yesterday with victories in their final qualifying games.    Brazil clinched its 17th appearance in 17 World...
docs.lead_paragraph: The four-time champion Brazil and the three-time winner Germany qualified for the World Cup soccer finals next year in Japan and South Korea yesterday with victories in their final qualifying games. Brazil clinched its 17th appearance in 17 World Cups by defeating visiting Venezuela, 3-0, on two goals by Luizao and one by Rivaldo.
docs.abstract: Four-time champion Brazil and three-time winner Germany qualify for World Cup soccer finals next year in Japan and South Korea with victories in their final qualifying games (S)

docs.snippet: Ireland, which had qualified only twice before, clinched a spot in next year's World Cup soccer tournament yesterday. Even though Iran was a 1-0 winner in the match in Tehran, it was unable to overcome a two-goal deficit from the first game of the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ireland, which had qualified only twice before, clinched a spot in next year's World Cup soccer tournament yesterday. Even though Iran was a 1-0 winner in the match in Tehran, it was unable to overcome a two-goal deficit from the first game of the home-and-home series. Iran, which lost by 2-0 Saturday in Dublin, scored in the 92nd and final minute of the match with a header from Sirous Dinohammadi.
docs.abstract: Ireland defeats Iran, 1-0, and qualifies for 2002 World Cup soccer tournament (S)

headline.main: Ireland Wins Spot In the World Cup

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show. Museums

docs.snippet: Bogotá has a fine museum to display Fernando Botero, while Mexico City has great public palaces to exhibit Diego Rivera, David Alfaro Siqueiros and José Clemente Orozco. But for too long Latin America's 20th-century masters of painting have lacked...
docs.lead_paragraph: Bogotá has a fine museum to display Fernando Botero, while Mexico City has great public palaces to exhibit Diego Rivera, David Alfaro Siqueiros and José Clemente Orozco. But for too long Latin America's 20th-century masters of painting have lacked a permanent home in which to be viewed and appreciated together. That vacuum is being filled by the new Museum of Latin American Art of Buenos Aires, better known as Malba, its acronym in Spanish. It opened in September as a welcome respite for a city suffering through its longest and deepest recession in generations.
docs.abstract: Arts Abroad column on new Museum of Latin American Art of Buenos Aires (Malba), first permamnent home for paintings by Latin America's 20th-century masters; photo (M)

headline.main: 20th-Century Latin American Art Finally Gets a Home

docs.snippet: The long road back to respectability for the Fairleigh Dickinson men's team has taken it back to the N.C.A.A. Division I tournament after 11 years.     The Knights (12-6) and Coach Seth Roland were drawn against Boston College (10-7) yesterday in a...
docs.lead_paragraph: The long road back to respectability for the Fairleigh Dickinson men's team has taken it back to the N.C.A.A. Division I tournament after 11 years. The Knights (12-6) and Coach Seth Roland were drawn against Boston College (10-7) yesterday in a first-round match Friday in Princeton, N.J. The winner will advance to play the host Tigers in the second round on Sunday.

docs.snippet: Brian McBride, sidelined since rib surgery on Aug. 30, was among 28 players selected yesterday for the United States men's roster for its Dec. 9 exhibition soccer game at South Korea.     Coach Bruce Arena went with a roster entirely from Major...
docs.lead_paragraph: Brian McBride, sidelined since rib surgery on Aug. 30, was among 28 players selected yesterday for the United States men's roster for its Dec. 9 exhibition soccer game at South Korea. Coach Bruce Arena went with a roster entirely from Major League Soccer, bypassing his European-based players. The team will gather Sunday in Chula Vista, Calif., and leave for Asia on Dec. 3. The game will be played at Seogwipo, one of the sites of next year's World Cup.
docs.abstract: US soccer coach Bruce Arena selects players for men's roster for exhibition game against South Korea (S)

docs.snippet: Passions are running high and are expected to reach the boiling point Sunday when Australia and Uruguay play for the final World Cup berth at Centenario Stadium, the second game of a home-and-home playoff.    Australia, the Oceania division champion,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Passions are running high and are expected to reach the boiling point Sunday when Australia and Uruguay play for the final World Cup berth at Centenario Stadium, the second game of a home-and-home playoff. Australia, the Oceania division champion, and Uruguay, the fifth-place team from the South American qualifying, will decide the last of the 32 spots for next year's World Cup in Japan and South Korea. Australia took a 1-0 lead by winning the first game in Melbourne. But Uruguay -- which won World Cup titles in 1930, when it was the host of the competition, and in 1950 -- now has the home-field advantage.
docs.abstract: Australia and Uruguay to play for final World Cup soccer berth (S)

headline.main: Last World Cup Spot at Stake

docs.snippet: Uruguay gained the 32nd and final spot in next year's World Cup, beating Australia, 3-0, yesterday in Montevideo, Uruguay, to win the home-and-home playoff on total goals.     This will be the first appearance in the World Cup since 1990 for Uruguay,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Uruguay gained the 32nd and final spot in next year's World Cup, beating Australia, 3-0, yesterday in Montevideo, Uruguay, to win the home-and-home playoff on total goals. This will be the first appearance in the World Cup since 1990 for Uruguay, twice a Cup winner.
docs.abstract: Uruguay defeats Australia, 3-0, winning final spot in World Cup soccer tournament (S)

docs.snippet: Shalrie Joseph and St. John's Coach Dave Masur believe that sometimes to move forward you have to be willing to move backward first.     Joseph, a senior from Brooklyn, led the Red Storm with 14 goals in 2000.
